conbody.p: As a final note, I'd just like to give some general i18n advice. Let's say you have an application for selling turtles. You're going to use the word "turtle" in multiple places, like "You have added 4 turtles to your cart." and "You have purchased 4 turtles, congratulations!" As a programming, you'll immediately notice the code reuse potential: we have the phrase "4 turtles" twice. So you might structure your message file as:
conbody.codeblock: AddStart: You have added AddEnd: to your cart. PurchaseStart: You have purchased PurchaseEnd: , congratulations! Turtles count@Int: #{show count} #{plural "turtle" "turtles"}
conbody.p: STOP RIGHT THERE! This is all well and good from a programming perspective, but translations are not programming. There are a million things that could go wrong with this, such as:

ul.li: Some languages might put "to your cart" before "You have added."
Maybe "added" will be constructed differently depending whether you added 1 or more turtles.
There are a bunch of whitespace issues as well.

conbody.p: So the general rule is: translate entire phrases, not just words.
